segments.text: First of all, I need to ask, because what this is going to do is it's going to go into the archives, kind of collection of interviews we have at A&M, so is it okay if you wind up here?
No.
Okay.
First, can you give your rank, name rank, where you were stationed, that kind of thing?
Okay.
My name is Kirby B. Terry.
I was a major in the Medical Corps.
I entered Vietnam and was assigned to Americal Division.
Um, and I was a clearing company commander for about six months.

And following that, I spent six months in two other hospitals, one in, uh, An K, North, uh, Central Highlands, and, uh, spent three months in, uh, Quignon, uh, which is on the coast about midway down Vietnam.
What do you, um,
What years were you there?
When did you...
I was there from October 68 to October 69.
So that's right after you were there, right after the Tet Offensive.
Yeah, the Tet Offensive was in January 68.
I arrived in October 68.
We also had a Tet Offensive in 1969, but it was much smaller.
Where were you stationed in the United States when you were doing your training there?
Well, I entered the Army in...
El Paso, Texas at William Beaumont Army Hospital in 1966.
As a first lieutenant, and received my commission and became a captain in the Army Medical Corps.
I was assigned to William Beaumont Army Hospital for a year.
I did my internship at William Beaumont Army Hospital.
From there, I then went to Tripler Army Hospital in Honolulu, Hawaii.
And spent a year
and general surgery there.
Following this I spent three months at the Army Field Service School in San Antonio, Texas, where I received all my basic orientation and pre-Vietnam training skills.
Then from there I went directly to
Saigon, that's where I entered the country.
After spending a couple days of orientation there, I then flew to Chulalongkorn, which was up near Da Nang in the north part of South Vietnam.
You mentioned that you were given some training before going over there.
Could you talk a little bit about what kind of training you got a few months before you went to Vietnam?
We didn't really receive any combat training.
We received what we would consider, I think, defensive training.
We spent most of the month learning how to salute, how to recognize people of various ranks.
We went through the basic courses at Fort Sam Houston on weaponry and how to use a gas mask.
We learned how to read compass.
Took some hikes.
We did a lot of marching and drilling, but we didn't do any real... We weren't learning to be combat soldiers at all.
Did you get any cultural or training about how the people were going to react to you or language training, things like that?
We didn't get any language training, but we spent a good bit of time in the orientation classes trying to be taught how the people were going to react to us and how we should try to react to them.
Do you think any of this was effective at all?
Helpful?
Oh, I think it was quite effective.
Much more effective than if we'd had none, because most of us had very little understanding of how the Oriental people act and react.
Was it at all accurate?
Were they pretty close to what was going on?
I think so.
Yeah, I think so.
Then you also mentioned your orientation once you got to Saigon in July.
Could you talk a little bit about what that was?
Well, basically, when you get there, you hear cannons and stuff going off all the time, and people basically just try to orient you so that you can learn to tell incoming rounds from outgoing rounds.
So that for outgoing, then you obviously don't have to be concerned about them.
For incoming, you better get under the bed or get in the nearest hole.
All right.
They also passed out and assigned you weapons, that sort of thing, so that you had some protection.

For instance, I was assigned a .45 pistol and an M16 rifle and the usual flak jacket, helmet, so that I would have some protection because I was basically just in a staging area and nobody was watching out for us.
And then I was waiting until the flight
was assigned to me to go to July.
But if I had gotten lost or misplaced somewhere in between there, no one would have probably known exactly where I was or who I was.
Was that right?
Without my dog tags, you know, that sort of thing.
Did you experience a lot of, you know, being mortared in artillery fire, things like that, just at the bases and areas you were in, or was that pretty uncommon?
No.
At the time I arrived, that was pretty uncommon.
almost anywhere in Vietnam you were though, you would hear outgoing rounds all the time.
And that was basically from our hires.
And I always thought it was just a program they had to kind of keep everybody alerts and knowing that something was going on.
I think they just basically peppered the hillsides with with artillery shells all the time.
Was that mostly to keep
just to keep us aware that the war was on, or was it an effective thing against the Vietnamese that they see?
Well, I think it's kind of both, actually.
Because when you sit around eight hours a day with nothing at all going on, people start to get lackadaisical.
And if something's happening, it keeps you aware that the war's still going on, because when you get lackadaisical, that's when things usually happen and people get hurt.
It was also important, I think, to let Charlie know that we knew where he was,
And no matter where he was, when something was sighted from the air, somebody would shoot at it.
You mentioned that you were a clearing company commander.
Could you explain what that was and what your command was?
Yeah.
A clearing company in an infantry division is basically a group of about 107 to 122 men who...
whose assignment, like in World War II, was to stay behind the lines and clear people who had minor wounds, take care of them, keep them around a few days, and then send them back to combat.
If they were severely wounded, they would be sent on to a major hospital for more care.
In Vietnam, the clearing company was kind of an obsolete setup, except that we took care mostly of minor injuries and mostly skin problems,
because everybody had severe acne.
If they had acne, their acne acted up.
If they had, I mean they continually had problems with fungus infections in their feet and groin and hair and all those sort of things simply because they weren't dry most of the time.
So we took care mostly of minor medical injuries and minor surgical injuries.
The more major injuries at this time went directly over us to a hospital, which was two or three miles away.
And the hospital's where I went to later on after I served in this clearing company for six months.
What were some of the types of people who were under your command?
Most of the guys that were under my command were what I would consider like nursing type people.
They were trained combat medics.

and orderlies and a large number of them would go out with infantry units during the day for like two or three months at a stretch and then come back and work in this little clearing company for a while until they rested up and then they'd go back out with an infantry unit they were mostly people who would be like a licensed practical nurse and this sort of thing and we did have those 60 to 90 bed capability in our little hospital all the time there
Most of these guys were pretty educated.
Most of them had, all of them had high school educations.
Many of them had college educations and degrees.
And I expect most of them went into medicine or nursing or something of that nature later on.
Because they were mostly very highly interested in medical problems.
How risky of a job was that being a medic with an infantry corps?
Being a medic with an infantry corps was very risky.
A lot of guys would want to go do it, and then they'd do it a while, and then they'd try to get out of it if they could because it was a very dangerous job.
I would rate it as the second most dangerous job in Vietnam, really.
Who was the first?

I'd say helicopter piloting was the first because any time somebody got wounded, the helicopter pilot came in to rescue them, and the enemy could see the helicopter very easily if they shot the man, and they could probably shoot a helicopter, which was a lot bigger, and it was in the same vicinity.
The...
Medic, however, had to go treat the person who had just gotten shot as soon as he could get there.
And if one man got shot, it was very difficult to get to him without getting shot yourself.
And the Vietnamese didn't hold back at all in shooting medics as far as I could tell.
I mean, getting one man just meant the medic was going to be there in a little bit.
If you waited around, you could shoot him too.
And I think that's what happened lots of times.

It was a very dangerous job, plus the fact that once you got there and did what you could do for him, you were the guy closest to him, and you had to try to drag him out to a safety spot, and that was very dangerous also.
Were there, were there ever any racial problems you ever came across?
We talked a little bit about this in class.
We had a black historian come in to speak to us.
Did you ever run across anything like that while you were there?
fairly minor racial problems.
The clearing company that I was commander of had about probably 15% blacks assigned to it.

And we generally didn't have very much problem at all, except that if they didn't see that they were getting an equal shake about everything, they would complain about it more so than the average white person would, I thought.
But in general, I think they did a very good job.
They were very good soldiers, and they were very patriotic, and I was very pleased to have served with them.
And at the time you were in Vietnam, what do you feel was the goal of the U.S. military?
What did you see as what we were trying to accomplish at that point in time, right after Tet and until you left?

As an officer in the Medical Corps, I don't know that I really knew what the goal there was or what it was clearly stated to be because I didn't see anything that really looked like we were going towards a goal.

We were basically, at the time I was there, trying to win the hearts and minds of the people in order to get Vietnam back on its feet so that the South Vietnamese could take care of themselves against the North.
I thought it was poorly run most of the time and it seemed like it was a very disjointed effort.

It was obvious to me at least I thought we could have won the war very quickly had we wanted to and it seemed illogical to me to waste all those years and all those lives basically accomplishing nothing and after we were there
For about 13 years, we really didn't accomplish anything that I could tell.
So I really don't think there was ever a stated goal other than we were to win the hearts and minds of the people, get them strong enough to take care of themselves.
We weren't there, I don't think, to win over the North Vietnamese communists.
We were there to help the South Vietnamese get strong enough to take care of themselves.
And that's the nearest thing I can figure to a goal after...
almost 20 years now.
What do you think would have been a way to have won the war initially?
You said we could have spent a long time there and wasted a lot of lives.
What do you feel we could have done?
Well, I think we should have attacked the north right away if we were going to and bombed their munitions plants, areas where all their guns and their weapons were coming from.
and just had a concerted effort to wiped out all of their supplies.
I suppose our our superiors were afraid that if we did that Chinese would come in to help them.
However, it didn't appear that we were accomplishing anything the way we were doing it because one or two North Vietnamese communist could keep an entire division of 10 to 20,000 men

upset most of the time just by firing an occasional rocket into the large division compound and this would usually upset things for two to three hours so if one guy could do that three or four times a day he could keep that division from doing anything really worthwhile and we frequently saw that uh now then
You mentioned that we were trying to win the hearts and minds.
What types of things were you doing with the Vietnamese people in the area, things like that?
Well, we tried in almost every way we could to make them feel that they were doing a good job.

I myself and the medical company that I was commanding, we had what was called MedCap missions, M-E-D-C-A-P. And basically these were medical missions in which once a week in the afternoon we would go out to a village and give medical care.
Basically, what we did was treat people with acute illnesses, chronic illnesses.
We'd give them inoculations with pulled teeth.
We basically did things to try to make them trust us.
And that was probably our biggest mission because if the people were really sick or really were injured, they were brought into our hospitals almost immediately.
The people themselves, the villagers would bring them in?
Mm-hmm.
And they would be admitted.
If they could prove that they weren't a communist, they would be admitted and taken directly to a hospital.
We treated many, many civilians very frequently.
Do you think that they appreciated us being there, or were they mostly just, we were just another...
I can't really answer that.
Most of the people that I work with seem to appreciate us at a superficial level because we gave them jobs, we gave them money, we gave them food.
But as far as ever gaining their confidence, I'm not sure we ever did that.
in the time period that I was there at least.
We'd been there for about 10 years before I got there.
So I don't think we really ever accomplished that goal.
Was communication a very big problem with the people?
Were interpreters pretty much available for you to use?
Yeah, we always had interpreters.
available and communications were just no problem at all.
Communications in the country was also excellent because there were very good radio and telephone contacts everywhere.
And you could usually reach help somewhere no matter where you're at.
But as far as working with people and understanding their immediate problems, that was never much of a problem for as I could tell.
because the interpretation was very good.
Were there many non-military groups that were doing similar things, like the Red Cross, Catholic Church, those type?
Were you involved with anything?
Well, the ones that I mainly saw were the Red Cross.

There were also a good number of civilians there doing things for our government, and I don't know exactly who paid them, but they were there building roads and building bridges and building new buildings for us, and they basically were just Caucasians from
almost anywhere who were just paid as civilians to work there.
They were non-military people.
They didn't fight or do anything.
They were just helping build.
The other groups that I saw were there were a good number of Australians there.
There were a good number of people from New Zealand who were working as advisors.
I don't know that they were actually fighting.
There was they did a good bit of medical missionary also.
There were a lot of Koreans
soldiers there, the Iraqs.
And they were very good soldiers and I think their stated goal was to help the Vietnamese in any way they could win the war.
And they were some of the finest soldiers I ever saw.
Did you ever notice any racial tensions between the Vietnamese and the Koreans?
I don't think I did because I was never around where they lived.
I just saw them here and there and took care of them when they were sick.
But the
Koreans, I thought, were very good soldiers.
They were very well trained.
They were slightly arrogant, and I think they kind of looked down upon the Vietnamese.

And in general, rather than working closely with the Vietnamese, it seemed to me that they were assigned to their own units, like the ROC unit would go out and do everything all by itself, and they didn't...
particularly mess around with the Vietnamese at all.
They did things the way they wanted to when they went out to accomplish a mission.
Yeah, that's basically the way we've talked about it, and it's been just like that.
They've been separated, because historically, that's a lot of thousands of years that they've been racially different from each other.
Now, as a commander, you know, were you ever involved with, you know, problems with getting supplies and things like that, and having to
really work with the Vietnamese to get that or the bureaucracy?
Well, we had to work with the bureaucracy a good bit to get what we needed.
The Vietnamese had almost nothing.
We had the best of everything in the way of medical supplies.
We were probably better equipped than the average hospital in the United States.
And the rumor was that if you were injured in Vietnam, you were probably better off than if you had been injured in front of a hospital in the United States because within
7 to 10 minutes after an injury occurred, there was usually a helicopter there to take care of that wounded person and bring him to the hospital.
So they were actually getting medical care within 10 to 15 minutes most of the time.
And in general, the infantry units were told, when you establish your very first contact, you should put in an order for a helicopter immediately.
That way, if anybody gets hurt, the helicopter will be there in a few minutes.
If nobody gets hurt, then you just cancel the order.
And we commonly would see people who had been injured less than 30 minutes by the time we saw them.
That's pretty amazing.
It really is.
Now, you know, on the base, I'm sure there were a lot of times when you didn't have things to do and all that.
What was sort of the life like?
What went on on the base?
Well, there was only about three or four things to do around the average division compound, and each company had its own division.
mess hall and that sort of thing.
We also had officers clubs that at each division level and there were probably several of them and the officers would usually go there in the evening if they had time.
The non-commissioned officers had the same kind of club also and they would frequent it in the evenings.
Most people, you know, wrote
letters home, or dictated letters home.
We all had little tape recorders.
We could send the tapes back and forth.
Many of us organized educational facilities.
I started teaching some anatomy and physiology classes.
And some of the orderlies and medics who were wanting to get further degrees would take the class that I taught in anatomy and physiology.
And it was through the University of Maryland.
They would actually get college credit for it.

The worst thing about most wars is most people aren't very busy and they they're not occupied, except maybe for 14 hours a day that work at somewhere, eight hours a day, then they have two or three, four hours of whatever and then the rest of the time they had free.
Our groups had a lot of physical activities.
We had basketball goals and volleyball goals and
We frequently played various kinds of ball games, pitched horseshoes, pitched washers.
We also had television, which was available in most base camps.
And television was about a week old by the time you saw it.
It was shipped in.
It's on videotape.
So you would find out what happened a week later.
But most of the shows you watch on television, it doesn't matter when they're recorded, actually.
And it's kind of entertaining.
So that's basically how most people spend their time.

And we've, in some of the lectures we've had, we've had some guest speakers who've come in, and we had one recently who talked about, was talking about the films of the war, and he specifically mentioned MASH.
You know, I had always assumed it was a war about Korea, but actually he said that it was a war about Vietnam placed in Korea.
Would you draw that correlation in any way, this being his doctoral hospital?
I don't know.
I never thought of it that way before.
I've never seen the...
seen the correlation.
I think after I haven't watched MASH many times in the last 20 years, probably only 15 or 20 times.
And I think MASH was basically a movie about the medical core in any war though, and it doesn't particularly matter which one it was.
I think that's probably probably applies if it would apply
as well as Vietnam or Korea as any place else.
Because he had stressed that, you know, how the craziness of it all was, how, you know, the boredom and just the anxieties.
That was all very accurate about Vietnam, I can say that.
Plus, the helicopter changed the face of the war, I think, because people could be flown directly to a battle site rather than having to be jeeped up or walked up.
If some action was really going on and you needed replacements, they would fly them in immediately.
It also made medical care 100% different, too,
simply because, you know, you get to the hospital very quickly when you're injured.
In World War II, it might be a day or two before you got to a medical facility.
That's an interesting correlation.
I hadn't heard that before.
Now, how was the protection of your base area?
Were you, you know, it was a pretty secure area, or were you ever, did you ever seem like you were in danger at any point in time?
No, I don't think, I never felt in danger.
At one time,
When I was in July, we lived about 100 yards from the fence, and all there was between our huts and the fence were our tents, actually, was a road and some blank land.
And then out near the fence, there were guard posts all along the fence.
They were occupied mostly at night by guard people.
You never knew whether they were alert.
If somebody had come through the fence, they could have gotten to our tents very quickly and caused all sorts of trouble.
But I don't think most of us ever worried about that at all.
It's just one of the things, when you're there, you just accept it after a while that if they get in and get to you, that's all there is to it.
There's nothing you can do about it anyway, so you just don't worry about it.
Okay.
And what were some of the,
your duties are on campus.
What were some of the more pleasant and some of the more unpleasant things you had to do?

Well, each morning as a company commander, somebody usually woke me up about 7 o'clock to sign the duty roster, and that had to be filled out for the day, finishing up the 24 hours, and then I had to sign my signature that it was accurate.
Usually after this, I got out and showered and shaved, and our shower was a fuel tank that had been emptied
washed out and filled with cold water.
And it had a faucet on the bottom of it so we would spend a very short time in that cold water in the morning waking up.
And then get dressed and go to the mess hall and have usually a fairly traditional breakfast if you wanted it of eggs and meat, bacon, coffee, and some juice.
Then we would usually make rounds in our little hospital

for maybe an hour and then either go do some minor surgery or work on sick call, which we would basically be seeing people from the battalion level who needed further medical care, and they would be brought over to us in a helicopter by jeep.

Our major things that we took care of all day were basically these major skin problems I told you about, where people just couldn't wear their boots, they couldn't walk, they couldn't carry their packs.
We also saw a lot of malaria.
There was also a lot of diarrhea and dysentery and nausea and vomiting.
And these minor problems were what we had to take care of most of the time.
It just took a few days for a guy to get calmed down and get his confidence back and get to eating so he could go back to his own unit.
And we did basically take care of a lot of injuries in this particular location.
They were mostly minor surgical and major medical problems.
I wonder about, you mentioned some of the records keeping and things like that.

Was it your belief that most of that was all pretty accurate and things like that, things that came through your command or... Oh, you're talking about body counts or... Well, yeah, that, but yeah, I'm sure you probably worked too, that was mostly with the, I'm sure you worked too involved.
Yeah.

But, you know, just the day-to-day things where they just, people would get lazy and just, oh, well, it's... No, I think the record keeping was done pretty accurately by most people because there was always at least two or three levels of people checking everything.

For instance, in our clearing company, this daily record that had to be compiled and had to be signed each morning gave a summary of what happened there for 24 hours, how many sick people we saw, how many we treated, how many we released, how many teeth were pulled, how many x-rays were taken, how many shots were given.
I think it was all quite accurate.
From my level as a company commander, though, it then went to battalion.
and somebody there looked it over and then went to division level and it was filed away somewhere then.
Would you say all that record keeping that had to be done, everything detailed, was that really necessary or was it just like a waste of time?
No, I think it was necessary.
The problem is at the time when you're doing it, it seems kind of like a waste of time, but four years later the historical part of it I think will be very accurate because we kept good records.
And I think it's essential to keep good records, particularly in today's world of liability.
The accurate record keeping that we learned and did there, I think, is still what you need to do today, if not more so.
Now, what were some of your other missions in the more remote areas that you would do other things than just be stationed at your hospital?
Could you explain some of the other things you might have done?
Well, other than going out in the villages on what we call MedCap missions, once a month we would maybe get to go to Da Nang, which is 50 miles away, and we'd have to ride an airplane, which took
You know, you had to go out and sit around all day long to wait for the airplane, and you would drive denying, and you'd have to find somebody sort of to stay with when you got there.
And we would usually do this on Friday, and then on Saturday morning there was what was called an I-Corps, number one corps, medical meeting.
And it was basically just an attempt of physicians in the I-Corps, which was the northern third of Vietnam, to...

keep up on things and at this meeting we would give reports on what we've been doing and what was happening and that we were here lectured many times on how to take care of various kinds of injuries or various kinds of medical problems there would usually be demonstrations sometimes of uh that demonstrate the kind of equipment that they've captured from the north vietnamese or from vietcong and i have pictures of many of the things that i saw that worked

on display for us and we were really surprised and amazed how well they were equipped in their aid stations and in their little hospitals that were probably underground someplace because they had regular operating facilities I think in many areas for taking care of their wounded.
And we've read about the ones that have just had fabulous networks of tunnels with all hospital facilities.
I never saw any of those but I heard about them and I think they were probably there
One of the other things that we would do, I would sometimes go out with the Red Cross people to contact soldiers for emergency messages back home.
Usually if a soldier's family had a death in the family, they would try to hold up the funeral until the soldier could be gotten home.
That was one of the biggest services, I think, of the Red Cross was taking care of emergency situations for a soldier and his family.
And that was very well taken care of, I think, in most cases.
And the average soldier could be probably back in the United States in about three to four days from the time he received word of a death in the family.
Were you ever stationed in an area where you were having to treat a lot of serious injuries, people coming in?
Yes, I was.
After the first six months in July, I then went to a hospital facility where I got to spend six more months.
And three months of that was in on K. I think it's spelled a n capital k h e. That was in the Central Highlands and I was with the 17th field hospital there.
I was basically assigned as a assistant surgeon.
which meant that I couldn't initiate most surgery by myself, but I helped other surgeons who were fully trained, since I'd only had two years of surgery at the time.
It was an extremely good experience for me because I worked with two fully trained people all the time, and it was basically like a residency training program.
These two guys had just finished their residency, and they were very interested in teaching me anything they could, and I was very interested in learning.
So basically,
I helped them with everything that they did, and they let me do as much as I could do.

In many cases, when we would be covered up with injuries, and they were very severe injuries in this particular area, lots of gunshot wounds, landmine wounds, pungi stick wounds, I would be starting a case, opening up the abdomen of the injured person or whatever was required,

one of the fully trained people would then come over and help me take care of the major problem or take care of it himself, then I would be allowed to go ahead and close that person's abdomen, which is what happens in most residency programs.
The beginning surgeon gets to do the easier parts, such as opening and closing, and then the fully trained person does the major operation itself.
And that's basically the role I had there.
What were the conditions of most of the men you saw as coming in there yet?
were they mostly gunshot wounds, landmines, things like that?
How long had they been around and things like that?
Well, most of the people we saw were very freshly injured, such as almost always within an hour.
And they were gunshot wounds, fragment wounds from mines, grenades, mortars, rocket attacks, and pungi stick wounds.
Pungi stick wounds were fairly frequent because people, as they walked through the jungle, would
run on these fungi sticks which were a very sharp angled bamboo stake.
They usually had feces smeared on them so they would cause an infection in the person's leg and they required a lot of surgical intervention simply because you would have to
make an incision around the wound itself and excise a little bit of it, but you would also have to go inside and do what was called a fasciotomy.

Open up the fascia around the muscles that that pungi stick had penetrated because the infection would make those muscles swell up and they would become gangrenous if you didn't allow them to swell because the pressure had to be relieved.
It seemed like you were making a very serious operation out of a very small injury, but if you didn't do it that way, they many times wound up losing a large amount of muscle or even their limb.
Let's see.
Then did you also... Let me see.
Oh, from the mines.
What kind of injuries would be sustained from a landmine injury?
Well, there were several kinds of mines.

Claymore mines were some of the more common ones and Claymore mines were basically a kind of a broad shaped mine that had a lot of explosive behind the pellets which were then propelled forward when a mine went off and they would many times be designed to cover a large area above the ground and you could like cover a whole road or something like that with one of these mines.
so that anything that was coming down the road would probably get hit by one of these mine fragments.
We saw a lot of makeshift mines also that were made by various people, mostly Vietnamese, from bombs that hadn't exploded or from rockets or mortars that hadn't exploded.
And they would hook them up to some sort of detonating device and blow up vehicles on the road, blow up people out in the jungle.
They were very good at making mines out of what we thought were dead bombs and dead equipment.
When you were treating these injuries, you didn't see a lot of serious injuries.
Was it hard for you to treat them and know that you were just going to send them right back into combat?
No, I don't think so.
I don't think that really ever crossed your mind.
It's just like when you're taking care of a sick civilian anywhere else in the world.
Your job is to get him back to the workplace so he can do what his job in life is.
And in a combat situation, it's very much the same.
It wasn't the kind of situation where you had a real personal relationship with the people.
If it had been one of your friends or relatives, it might have been different.
But your job was to keep the fighting man healthy, and that was what we did.
Did you ever treat any of the Arvin soldiers or even BC?
Oh, yeah, we treated Arvin soldiers all the time.
We commonly treated the Rock soldiers.
We treated the Mountain Yard soldiers when we were in the Central Highlands.
We treated anybody that was brought in, and that many times included BC soldiers and North Vietnamese soldiers.
They had already had their weapons and everything taken away from them.
They were injured.

Many times these guys would be very sick because they might have been shot a day or two ahead of time and hidden somewhere, and they would come in all bloated up and very, very ill by the time we saw them.
We frequently had to amputate limbs simply because they had very little primary medical care, and by the time we saw them,
They were very sick and in severe condition, and they many times did require amputations just to get rid of a very infected part of their body.
And what about the Arvin troops themselves as soldiers?
How do you think they performed?
Well, I was never very impressed with the Arvin soldiers in general.
I think the average American soldier that I was around seemed to think of them as like Boy Scouts, like we were training junior soldiers to do a job.
And they were basically kind of treated as though they weren't really capable of doing this themselves right now.
They were sort of just supposed to stand around and watch how the Americans did it.
And I thought they were probably treated as inferiors
And most of them that I saw acted as though they were inferiors.
Do you think had they been treated differently, they wouldn't behave differently?
I don't know.
I don't guess I can answer that because I never saw any of them for any long period of time to see how they developed after they became experienced.
I always thought they basically took advantage of our situation.
They let our men
go out and do most of the fighting when they could, and they sort of stood around and watched or guarded the town while somebody else was out doing the fighting.
I was not impressed with the urban soldiers at all.
How about the Saigon government?
Do you feel that the Saigon government was really worthy of our support and capable of controlling the country themselves?
Well, looking at it 20 years later, I probably...
don't think that they were worthy of it.
And I'm not sure exactly why that is.
But at the time I was there, I didn't have any idea what was going on militarily or politically.
And I can't ever remember talking to anybody who basically strongly thought we should have been in Vietnam.
Most people were just there because they were told to go and it was their assignment.
I don't think we had any
I don't think we had a lot of patriotic reason to be there as soldiers, and we didn't feel that we were there doing some great job for some nation that needed us dramatically.
It was just a job for you.
It was just an assignment, that was it.
And from all the people I saw who were privates all the way up to generals, I really never talked to anybody who thought we probably should have been there.
And we were doing a lot of good.
I don't think that was the average person's viewpoint.
Now, when you were in Vietnam, were you ever aware, before you went or while you were there, of the rising anti-war sentiments and protests and trouble back home that was brewing?
No.
When I was there in 1968, 69, that was the year the man landed on the moon first.
It was the year Ted Kennedy drove off the bridge at Chappaquiddick.
We heard a little bit about that.
Those were the two big events.
And I recall, I think, that they happened the same week so that Teddy's problem never got as nearly as much publicity as it would have had we not landed a man on the moon that same week.
Well, we really never heard much about what was going on back home.
Everything we read was in the daily newspaper that was printed by the Army.
And so unless you got a paper from home, which might take a couple weeks to get there, you didn't know much at all.
And I was not aware at all of the sentiment back home about the war.
We would occasionally hear something about university students acting up or protesting, but I didn't know anything really about it.
How about after you came back?

Well, after I came back, I became very aware of that because I came back to Fort Eustis, Virginia, which was fairly close to Richmond, and I knew the students were acting up on those campuses at that time, and people were beginning to demand all over the United States that we pull out of Vietnam, and it seemed like probably the thing to do to me
It seemed proper for us to pull out simply because we'd been there so long and had never really given a concerted effort to win the war, either for the Vietnamese or to make them win the war.
And I thought if we weren't going to really give it 100%, then we should pull back and get out of it, which we did shortly after that.
What about Nixon's handling then of the Vietnamization process, getting him out and trying to turn control of the Vietnamese?
Do you think he did a good job or a fair job
I don't know if I can answer that or not, because I didn't know that much about the political side of it.
I was still in the Army at the time, and I was real busy as a surgeon.
I thought he did what was proper, basically, in getting us out of there as quickly as he could once a decision was made.
While I was in Vietnam, Lyndon Johnson was still president, and I was there during the time we had 500,000 men there.
Obviously, if we had put out a big effort, 500,000 of us could have probably done a lot more than we did because we really were there basically occupying the country.
We weren't there fighting war, in my experience, in my opinion.
One set of figures we come across pretty often in my class is that there were 500 or 540,000 people there, but of that number, only 80,000 were combat troops.
That's probably right.
There's just a lot of backup.
Yeah, I think that's probably right.
While I was there also, he started bombing the North.
And I don't know that that really changed things very much, as far as we were concerned.
I was also there during the year when Ho Chi Minh died.
And that was kind of an interesting experience because I was in a hospital that was basically a prisoner of war hospital.
We took care of mostly prisoners of war.
And that was in Quy Nhon, a huge,
Q-H-I.
It's Y-H-O-N, I think, or something like that.
This was basically a... We took care of a lot of our own troops, but we also...
It was a prisoner of war hospital.
Once the prison... We took care of prisoners immediately after they came in, and then we also kept them around for a while until they were assigned to go to a...
Army unit to be in.
It was like a prison camp, yeah.
But a large number of those guys we had had amputations and that sort of thing, and they stayed around a pretty long period of time.
And I got to know some of them, and I grew to like and trust most of the North Vietnamese that I took care of.
I thought they were much more honest and probably
Harder working and much better soldiers than the South Vietnamese that I was around.
During the time that I was there when Ho Chi Minh died, it was very interesting because all the guys who, when they heard about his dying, wore a black sleeve patch made out of something.
And we never...
interfered in any way with their doing this because it was their way of mourning for their leader.
And I think it was what any soldier would have done had his leader died.
I only hope that our soldiers did the same thing for our president when he died during that same time frame.
Did you notice any mourning with the southerners, the South Vietnamese?
Did they feel a loss?
I don't think the South Vietnamese felt lost at all.
Most of them seemed to feel that...
I don't...

Most of the South Vietnamese that I was around were not highly educated people historically, and I don't think that they felt very much for Ho Chi Minh or that they really believed that he was trying to save Vietnam and such.
And from what I've seen, it looks to me like he dedicated his whole life to
saving Vietnam as a whole and when he couldn't get help one place and he went somewhere else to get the help.
